p.seg: In the first month of the spring
the sun is in the constellation Encampment.
Towards the evening the Triad Star is in the centre,
in the morning the Tail Star is in the centre.
The days for this month are jiǎ and yī (days one and two of the sixty day cycle),
the High Ancestor for this month is Tài Háo (i.e. Fú Xī),
the spirit for this month is Gōu Máng,
the animals for this month are the scaly ones,
the tone for this month is jué,
the pitch of this month fits the Great Budding,
the quantity of this month is eight,
the flavour of this month is the sour,
the smell of the month is that of rankness,
the sì-sacrifice for the month is that at the door,
and when jì-sacrificing to Heaven during this month one gives priority to the spleen.
The east wind melts what is frozen,
the hibernating animals begin to move.
The fish come up to the ice,
the otters sacrifice fish,
migrating geese head north.
(During this month) the Son of Heaven resides in the left appartment of the Green Yang Hall,
he rides a phenix bell chariot,
he yokes "blue-dragons" (as horses) to his carriage,
he takes along (and floats) on his carriage green streamers,
he wears green clothes,
he wears green jade,
he eats wheat and mutton,
and the vessels used in this month have openwork and are not watertight.
This month
there is the Opening up of Spring.
Three days before the Opening up of Spring
the Grand Archivist announces this to the Son of Heaven, saying:
"On such-and-such a day there will be the Opening up of Spring,
and the predominant cosmic power is in Wood."
The Son of Heaven then starts fasting.
On the the day of the Opening of Spring
the Son of Heaven in person leads the Three Dukes, the Nine Ministers, the feudal lors, and the dignitaries in welcoming spring at the Eastern Suburb-altar.
Then he turns back,
and he then offers ritual rewards for their attendance to the dukes, senior ministers, feudal lords, and dignitaries at the court.
He gives out orders to his Prime Minister to spread his generosity and issue his orders,
to enact felicitations and to exercise generosity,
to reach the people at large below.
The felicitations and the presents are then carried out,
and there is nothing that is not adequate.
He then orders the Grand Archivist
to take care of the Statutes and to uphold the law,
to take administrative responsibility for the movements of the Heavens, of sun, moon stars and constellations,
that their positions and displacements are not in deviation from the rule,
that they never come to deviate from the rules,
in order to make the beginning (of the year) standard.
As for this month
the Son of Heaven prays for grain harvest to the Highest Sovereign on the first day.
Then one selects an appropriate day
and the Son of Heaven in person takes along the ploughing tools
and he puts these between the armed guard and the driver.
He then leads the Three Dukes, the Nine Senior Ministers, the feudal lords and the dignitaries along to personally till the field of the High Ancestor.
The Son of Heaven will make three pushes,
the Three Dukes will make five pushes,
and the Senior ministers, feudal lords and dignitaries will make nine pushes.
When he has got back,
he takes up a beaker (and makes a pledge) in the the Great Hall of Repose, the ancestral temple,
and the Three Dukes, the Nine Senior Ministers, the feudal lords and the dignitaries are all in attendance,
and he declares this the Toast for Work Well Done.
During this month
vital energies of Heaven descend
vital energies of Earth ascend,
Heaven and Earth are in unison,
the vegetation proliferates and sprouts.
The king publicly announces the tasks of agriculture.
He commands that the Field Inspectors take up temporary residence at the Eastern Suburb Altar
that they all renovate their boundary markings,
and that they take care with the straightness of paths and roads,
that they expertly assess mountains, slopes, impasses, plains and marshes,
and to what the soils are appropriate for,
and where the five kinds of grain grow,
so as to instruct and guide the people,
and that they must unfailingly participate in these activities in person.
When the business in the fields have been announced
and one has fixed the guidelines beforehand,
then the peasants will not be confused.
In this month
the king orders the Coordinator of Music to enter the school and to direct the dancing practice,
whereupon he pays close attention to the statutes of sacrifice:
he commands that in sacrificing to the mountains, forests, streams and marshes,
no female animals be used.
he forbids the felling of trees, so that one does not overturn bird's nests,
he ensures that people do not turn over bird's nests,
and that one does not kill young animals, foetuses, new-born animals or birds,
that one does not hunt the new-born fawns and does not collect bird's eggs,
that one does not organise gatherings of large groups,
that one does not set up inner and outer city walls,
that one covers up skeletons and buries decaying bones.
In this month
it is not acceptable that one should deploy military force,
and if one does use military force there is bound to be disaster from Heaven.
When armed forces are not led into the field (by others)
it is not acceptable that such action should start from oneself.
One should not change the Way of Heaven,
one should not disrupt the principles of Earth,
and one should not disturb the guidelines for Man.
If in the first month of spring one acts on the orders for the summer,
then wind and rain will not be seasonal,
plants will wither earlier than they should,
and in the state there will then be an atmosphere of fear.
If one acts on the orders for the summer (during this first month)
then the people will suffer great pests,
storms and thunderstorms will frequently occur,
pigweed, wild millet, bitter fleabane, and wormwood will all thrive (in the fields, ruining crops).
If one practises the orders for winter (during this first month),
then floods will have their deleterious effects,
frost and snow will arise on a large scale,
and the first seeds will not get into the ground.
What first gives birth to things
is Heaven;
what nurtures them to completion
is Man.
One who can nurture what Heaven has brought to life and who will not interfere with it, is called a Son of Heaven.
When the Son of Heaven takes an initiative,
it is the sort of action which has as its motivating background the keeping unimpaired what is from Heaven.
It is from this motive that officials are established.
Establishing officials is for the keeping unimpaired what is alive.
The confused rulers of the present generation
when they have many officials, but on the contrary they harm living creatures through them,
then they lose sight of the very purpose for which they established them.
This is like training and building up armed forces:
that is in order to guard against enemies.
But nowadays when as they train their armed forces, and they on the contrary attack themselves,
then they surely lose sight of the purpose for which they were training and building up their armies.
Now it is the nature of water to be clear and pure,
but as for soil, it will disturb the water
and therefore it does not get to be pure.
It is the nature of man to be long-lived,
but external things interfere with him
and that is why he does not get to be long-lived.
As for external things
these are the means by which one nurtures one's nature,
but they are not that by which (in the end) things get nurtured.
Now as for the people of the present age
when the confused people for the most part nurture things with their nature
then they do not understand the real relative importance of things.
When they do not understand the real relative importance of things
then the important things are treated as unimportant
and the unimportant things are treated as important.
If one acts like this
then whenever one moves one will inevitably fail.
It is in this way that they make the ruler confused,
it is in this way that they make the ministers revolt,
it is in this way that they make sons go berserk.
If, of these three, the state has one,
then unless it is really lucky, it is bound to be ruined.
Now suppose that there is a tune before one
and when with one's ears one listens to it it one is bound to be pleased,
but after one has listened to it then it makes people deaf,
then one is bound to refuse to listen to it;
suppose there is a colour in front of one,
and when one looks at it with one's eyes one is bound to be pleased,
but after one has looked at it then it makes people blind,
then one will certainly refuse to look at such a colour.
suppose there is a delicacy before one,
and when with one's mouth one eats it one is bound to be pleased,
but after one has eaten it then it causes one to become dumb,
then one is bound to refuse to eat such a thing.
That is why the sages, when it comes to their relation to music, colours and flavours,
then they would opt for those that profit one's nature
and they would reject those that do harm to one's nature.
That is the Way of preserving this nature intact.
The reason why this age sets great store by wealth
is that those who for the most part are confused in their relation to sounds, colours and tastes
seek after them day and night,
and if by dint of good luck they get it these things then they indulge in these.
When they indulge in these
how can their natures fail to suffer damage.
If 110 000 men wield their bows and all shoot at one aim,
then under all circumstances the aim will be hit.
As for the myriad things in their splendour
if one sets out to harm one living creature with these
then that living creature will in every case suffer injury;
but if one uses them to serve the interests of one living creature
then that living creature will in every case thrive and grow.
Therefore the sages, when they organised the myriad things,
aimed to keep intact what was from Heaven (in them).
When one's endowment from Heaven is unimpaired then one's spirit is harmonious,
then one's eyes are sharp-sighted,
then one's ear's are sharp of hearing,
then one's nose is keen to smells,
then one's mouth is sensitive to tastes,
then one's 360 joints are all function as they should.
A person like this
will be trustworthy without speaking,
will get things right without planning,
will be successful without thinking carefully.
His vital essence will pervade Heaven and Earth,
his spirit will cover the universe of space and time.
In his relation to outward things there is nothing that he does not accept,
and there is nothing that he does not encompass,
like Heaven and Earth.
If he rises to become Son of Heaven he will not become pround,
if he sinks to become an ordinary fellow he will not grumble.
This is called a person who keeps his integrity unimpaired.
If one is noble and rich but does not understand the Way
as it happens this is sufficient to lead to disaster
and it would be better one were poor and humble.
When one is poor it is hard to get things,
even if one wanted to go beyond this (and find something still worse), how could one do this?
"When abroad (on long distance travel), one uses a vehicle,
when at home (on short distance travel) one uses a carriage,
one aims in this way to make things comfortable for oneself
but we name these things contraptions that call up stumbling.
Through "fat meat and undiluted wine"
one aims to strengthen oneself,
bu we name this food that rots away the guts.
Through physical beauty and shining white teeth
and the music from Zhèng and Wèy,
one aims to give oneself pleasure
but we(, on the other hand) call these things axes with which to atack one's natural endowments.
These three disasters
are brought upon one by honour and wealth.
Therefore if the ancients in some cases are not willing to become honoured or wealthy
this is because of the reason that they value life.
They were by no means making much ado of the fame (thus achieved),
they were concerned with the substance of the matter.
And so this exposition should be carefully examined.
VALUING THE SELF
Chuí was consummately skillful.
The reason why people feel no loving care for Chuí's fingers
but do feel loving care for their own fingers
is because of the advantage of having these/because they are theirs.
People do not feel fondness for the jade of Kūnshān, or for the pearls of the Jiāng and the Hàn rivers,
but they do feel fondness for any blue jade ring or a little jī-jade of their own,
because of the natural advantage of owning these.
Now one's life being something that one has
its benefit to one is surely on a large scale.
If one discusses its relative value to one
then being of the rank of a Son of Heaven does not bear comparison;
if one discusses the relative importance to one,
then being rich to be point of owning All under Heaven is not something one would exchange for it;
and when one discusses the question of safety and danger
if one morning one loses it (i.e. one's life)
one will not regain it "to the end of one's life".
These three things
are what the person possessed of the Way will carefully observe.
Now there are those who pay careful attention to this but do, on the contrary harm it,
and this is because they do not reach the essence of one's natural endowment and fate.
If one does not understand the essence of one's natural endowment and fate
then paying careful attention to life will serve no pupose.
This is like the (blind) music master in his fondness for his son
will not be able to avoid pillowing him on husks of grain
or it is like the blind man's nurturing his little child,
and just as it is thundering looking on as he is running about in the halls:
these people have defects and are unable to understand what they are to be careful about.
Now if one does not understand what to be careful with
then life and death, survival and ruin, acceptability and inacceptability
have not quite having begun to get distinguished.
And when these have not quite begun to be distinguished
then what one considers right is never right
and what one calls wrong is never wrong.
When one treats as right that which one considers as wrong
and treats as wrong what one considers as right,
this is called great confusion.
People like this
are those whom Heaven ruins through disaster.
If one governs one's person like this
one is bound to die, one is bound to meet disaster;
if one governs a state like this
it is bound to be destroyed, it is bound to be ruined.
This death, disaster, destruction and ruin
do not by any means come to pass of themselves:
it is confusion that calls them up.
Long life and the reaching of a solid standard (in life) are also like that.
Thus if he who has attained to the Way
does not investigate what he has called up,
but he investigates that which calls things up,
then there is nothing that can prevent him from reaching perfection.
This point one must make oneself thoroughly familiar with.
If Wūhuò pulls the tail of an ox violently
then the tail will be broken off and his strength will be exhausted,
but the ox cannot be made to walk.
This is because what he does goes against the grain.
Suppose a five foot boy pulls an ox by the nose ring
This is because what he does is in accordance with the nature of things.
The rulers of men of this age, and noble people,
no matter whether they are talented or incompetent,
all wish for a long life, and hope to see the light of day for a long time,
but if every day they go against their life
then wishing for it, what good will that do?
Whenever life is long,
this is because one goes along with things.
That which causes life not to go along withthings
are desires.
Therefore the Sage is bound to make it his first priority to properly adjusting his desires.
When one's house is large there will be a predominance of Yin,
when one's towers are high then there will be a predominance of Yang.
If there is a predominance of Yin on3e will (lose one's proper sense of balance and) be prone to stumble
if there is a predominance of Yang one will be lame:
these are the misfortunes of Yin and Yang not being properly adjusted.
Thus the former kings did not live in large dwellings
and they did not construct tall towers;
their dishes were neither varied nor particularly exquisit
their clothes were not excessively warm in any way.
If clothes are excessively warm then the meridians will get blocked.
and when the meridians are blocked then the vital energies cannot reach their destinations.
When dishes are varied and exquisit then the stomach gets replete,
and when the stomach is replete then one's innards will become very much bloated.
When the innards are very much bloated the vital energies do not reach out.
How can a long life be achieved following this method?
In ancient times, when the former sage kings built parks, hunting parks, gardens and ponds
as soon as these were sufficient to enjoy visually and to exercise oneself physically they would stop;
when they built houses, lodgings, towers and pavilions,
as soon as these were sufficient to keep heat and moisture away they would stop;
when they provided carriages, horses, garments and fur cloaks,
as soon as these were sufficient to give one's body comfort and keep one's physical frame warm they stopped.
when they provided drink and food and of wine,
as soon as these were sufficient to supplement/fit the dishes and filled one's empty stomach they stopped;
when they provided love songs and women, as well as (proper ritual) music,
as soon as these were enough to put at ease one's inborn nature and make oneself feel well they stopped.
These five things
were means by which the sage kings nurtured their inborn nature.
It is not that they were fond of parsimony and hated luxuriousness,
they just constantly moderated their inborn nature.
In former times, when the sage kings governed all under Heaven
they unfailingly gave priority to impartiality.
When there is impartiality then All under Heaven is in peace.
Peace is achieved on the basis of impartiality.
If one tries to survey the records of antiquity, (Chén Qíyóu adds: 失天下 before this line, unnecessarily.)
one finds that those who gained control over all under Heaven are many,
and when they gained control it was through impartiality,
but when they lost control it was unfailingly because of partiality.
In general, when a ruler is established on the throne
this arises from impartiality.
Therefore the Hóngfàn says:
"One should not be partisan, one should not be factitious.
The Way of a King is accommodating large-heartedness,
not to have any slants, not to have any partiality.
One should respectfully follow the rectitude of the king,
and one should under no circumstances be partial;
one should respectfully follow the Way of the king,
and one should under no cicrumstances commit acts of turpitude.
One should respectfully follow path of the ruler."
All under Heaven is not the all under Heaven of one person,
it is the all under Heaven of all under Heaven.
The harmonious blend of Yin and Yang
do not make one species grow,
the sweet dew and the seasonal rain
do not favour one creature over all others,
the ruler over the myriad people
does not fawn upon one person.
When Bó Qín was about to set out on a journey
he asked about how one might rule the state of Lǔ properly,
and the Duke of Zhōu said:
"Give benefit, but do not benefit from that."
In Chǔ* there was someone who had lost his bow,
He was unwilling to look for it,
saying:
"A man from Chǔ* has lost it,
a man from Chǔ* will have got it.
Why should one go on to look for it?"
When Confucius heard about this he said:
"If one cuts out the bit about Chǔ* it will be all right."
When Lǎo Dān hear4d about it he said:
"If one cuts out the bit about "man" it will be all right."
Thus Lǎo Dān attained to perfect public-spiritedness.
Heaven and Earth are large-minded/have a large perspective on things:
They bring forth creatures but do not treat them as children,
they bring things to perfection but will not treat them as his property,
and yet the myriad things all receive their bounty and receive their benefit,
and no one knows wherefrom they first arose.
This is also the charismatic power of the Three August Ones and the Five Sovereigns.
When Guǎnzhòng was ill
Duke Huán paid him a sickness visit,
and said:
"How ill you are, Guǎn Zhòng
you are very sick indeed!
The senior citizens in the capital do not make any secret of it.
Whom shall I pass on the state?"
Guǎn Zhòng replied:
"In the old days I have made every effort and used up all my intelligence,
and still it was not enough to understand things.
Now that my illness (could kill me) between morning and evening,
how should I be able to speak up?"
Duke Huán said:
"This is an important matter.
I do hope that you, will instruct my humble person on this."
Guǎn Zhòng acceded respectfully to this request
and he said:
"Whom does the Duke wish to make Prime Minister."
The Duke said:
"Would Bào Shūyá be acceptable?"
Guǎn Zhòng replied:
"This will not do.
I am on good terms with Bào Shūyá.
Bào Shūyá is by nature
quite pure and impeccable.
When he sees someone who is not as good as he
he makes no comparison with others (to emphasise his superiority).??????????
But once he has heard of another's faults
he will not forget them the rest of his life.
"If we must not stop our pursuit of this question,
then would Xī Péng be acceptable?
By nature Xī Pě2ng is such that
he has high aspirations and makes demands on those below,
he is ashamed that he is not as the Yellow Sovereign
and he feels sympathy for those who are not as good as he.????
In relation to the state
there are things he is uniformed about,
in relation to things
there are those which he does not fully understand,
when it comes to people
there are those with whom he is unacquainted.
If you will not put the matter to rest
then Xī Péng is acceptable.
The office of Prime Minister
is a great office to hold.
Those who hold a great office
should not be inquisitive about minor matters/in a petty way,
and they should not be clever in small matters/in a petty way.
Thus it says:
"The great carpenter does not hew wood,
the great cook does not shuffle bowls?????;
the paragon of courage does not fight,
the great army does not start invasions.
Duke Huán practised impartiality and he removed egotism and wickedness,
he employed Guǎnzǐ and became the leading personality among the Five Hegemons.
When he practised bias and favouritism towards those he liked
he employed Shù Dāo and insects came out of the door (behind which the duke lay, dead and unburied).
When humans are young they are relatively stupid
and when they grow up they get more clever.
Thus a clever person employing those who are selfish
is not as good as a stupid person employing those who are impartial.
Being drunk every day to make sure that one maintains impeccable dress,
aiming for private advantage to establish public good,
by being greedy and cruel to seek to become a true king,
this is something even a Shùn cannot do.
GETTING RID OF PARTIALITY
Heaven does not cover anthing with partiality,
Earth does not bear up anything with partiality,
the sun and the moon do not shine on anything with partiality,
the four seasons do not conduct themselves with partiality.
They act out their inner power and the myriad creatures get to grow.
A saying of the Yellow Sovereign says:
"Songs one should forbid people to give priority to,
female beauty one should forbid people to give priority to,
clothes one should forbid people to give priority to,
perfumes one should forbid people to give priority to,
delicacies one should forbid people to give priority to,
housing one should forbid people to give priority to.
Yáo had ten sons,
but he did not give (his royal title) to a son but handed it over to Shùn.
Shùn had nine sons,
but he did not give (his royal title) to a son but handed it over to Yǔ.
This was public-spirited/impartial in the extreme.
Duke Ping of Jìn asked Qí Huángyáng:
"They are short of a commander in Nányáng,
who will be acceptable to take charge of the place?
Qí Huángyáng replied:
"Xiè Hú would be acceptable."
Duke Píng said:
"But isn't Xié Hú your competitor/enemy?"
He replied:
"My lord asked about acceptability,
and did not ask about hostile relations."
Duke Píng said:
"All right."
In the event he did employ Qí Huángyáng.
The senior citizens in the state praised his excellence.
After a while
Duke Píng consulted Qí Huángyáng again and said:
"There is no chief of staff in the state,
who would be acceptable to fullfil this function?"
He replied:
"Wǔ would be acceptable."
Duke Píng said:
"But is not Wǔ your son?"
He replied:
"My lord asked about acceptability/suitability,
you did not ask about who was or was not my son."
Duke Píng said:
"Good."
And there again he employed Wǔ.
The senior citizens praised his excellence.
When Confucius was informed of this he said:
"Excellent,
Qí Huángyáng's point of view!
When raising an outsider to high office one does not avoid one's enemies/competitors;
when one raises an insider to high office, one does not avoid a candidate who is one's son.
Qí Huángyáng may properly be called impartial/public-spirited.
Among the Mohists there was a leader by the name of Fù Tun.
He lived in Qín.
His son had killed someone,
and king Huì of Qín said:
"Sir, you are of advanced age,
and you will by no means beget any more sons.
My humble person has already ordered the magistrate not to execute him.
(I hope) that you, Sir, will in this matter agree with my instructions."??????
Fù Tun replied:
"The law of the Mohists says:
'He who has committed murder must die,
he who has injured someone must suffer mutilating punishment.'
This is the means whereby we prevent murder and causing bodily harm.
Now preventing murder and the causing of physical harm
is the most important moral principle in all under Heaven.
Even if Your Majesty gives me a present of his favour in this instance
and orders the magistrate not to execute him,
still I, Fù Tun, cannot fail to uphold the law of the Mohists.
Fù Tun did not go along with King Huì,
and in the event they went on to kill the man (i.e. his son).
A son is the person one is most partial towards.
He was hard-hearted with whom one is selfishly partial towards so as to practice large moral principles.
The leader (of the Mohists) may properly be called impartial/public-spirited.
A kitchen worker will blend things into proper mixtures and will not presume to eat of them (himself),
and therefore he can become a cook.
Supposing that a kitchen worker blended things into proper mixtures but then ate them himself
then he cannot become a cook.
Rulers who qualify as kings or hegemons are also like that:??????
they execute the violent and show no selfish partiality
and so they establish the most talented men in all under Heaven.
That is why they can become kings or hegemons.
Suppose that ruler of the type of a king or a hegemon when executing the violent is selfishly partial with this,
then he also cannot function as a king or as a hegemon.
During the second month of spring:
the sun is is located in the constellation Legs.
At dusk the constellation Bow is at the centre,
and in the morning the Establishing Star is at the centre.
the days for this month are jiǎ and yǐ (the first and the second day of the cycle).
The Sovereign of this month is Tàihào,
the associated spirit is Gǒumáng.
The associated animals are the scaly animals,
the associated tone is jiǎo.
The pitch-standard fits the Pressing Bell.????
The associated number is eight.
The associated taste is sour,
and the assoicated smell is goaty rankness.
The associated sacrifice is at the door,
and in sacrificing priority is given to the spleen.
It begins to rain,
the peaches and the pears are in flower,
the golden oriole sings,
and the eagle turns into a turtledove.?????
The Son of Heaven resides in the Qīngyáng Great Temple,
rides a carriage with phoenix bells,
yokes up blue-dragon horses (sometimes written with horse radical beside the dragon!),
carries green-blue streamers on the carriage,
wears green-blue clothes,
wears green-blue jade,
eats wheat and mutton,
and his vessels are with openwork and let through air.???
During this month
one looks well after the sprouts,
one nurtures the very young,
and ensures the survival of those who are orphaned.
One selects a good day,
and commands the people to conduct the shè-sacrifices.
One gives orders to the officials
to inspect the prisons
and to remove the foot-fetters and manacles.
One should never carry out public displays of executed prisoners or beatings,
and one should interrupt legal proceedings.
During this month
the reddish-black birds (swallows?) will arrive.
When it arrives
one should sacrifice the suovetaurilia to the High Matchmaker.
The Son of Heaven will go along in person.
His queen and consorts will lead the nine royal concubines,
and they show proper polite respect to those whom the Son of Heaven has been with,
they are given bow cases to carry on their belts,
and one gives them bows as well as arrows in the presence of the High Matchmaker.
This month,
day and night are equally divided.
Thunder then reverberates more,
there begins to be lightning.
Hibernating insects all start moving,
opening their "doors" they first come out.
Three days before the thunder
one sounds the bells in order to issue an order to the innumerable people, saying:
"The thunder is about to reverberate.
If there are those whose behaviour does not observe prohibitions
will beget imperfect children
and there are bound to be inauspicious events and calamities."
When day and night are equally divided (of the same length),
then one unifies measures and weights,
one evenly adjusts the scales and weight stones,
one calibrates??? the (dipper and the bucket-measure:) volume measures,
one calibrates the steelyard scales.
During that month
those who work the fields seldom stop working,
and then one repairs one's gates,
and Bedroom Temple (ceremonial temple hall where the ancestors rest must be put in order).
One should never start large undertakings
which would interfere with the completion of agricultural work.
During this month
one does not drain the rivers and marshes,
one does not draw water from dykes and ponds,
one does not set fires in the mountain forests.
Then the Son of Heaven offers up a mutton sacrifice, and "opens the ice"????,
making his first solemn offering to the Bedroom Temple.
On the first dīng day
he issues orders to the Music Officer to enter the dancing hall and display the coloured silk.

Once when Kongjia, a sovereign of the house of Xia, was hunting at Mount Fu in Dongyang,
there was a great wind and the sky darkened.
Kongjia, lost and confused,
entered the house of a commoner.
At that very moment the woman of the house was giving birth.
Someone said,
"When the sovereign comes, it is a lucky day.
Your son is certain to enjoy extraordinarily good fortune.
Another person said,
"He is not equal to it.
Your son is certain to suffer from catastrophe."
The sovereign thereupon seized the child and returned home with him,
saying,
"If I make him my son,
who will dare harm him?"
When the boy grew to maturity,
it happened that a tent shifted,
causing its supporting post to split,
and a falling ax chopped off his foot. The boy was fit to become a gatekeeper.
kongjia cried,
"Alas!
suffering affliction
is a matter of fate after all!"
He then composed the song entitled, "Grinding an Ax".
This marked the beginning of tunes in eastern style.

The girl ordered a slave to spy on Yu at the southern slopes of Mount Tu.

This marked the beginning of the tunes in the southern style.
The dukes of Zhou and of Shao selected from these tunes the airs
that came to be known as "Zhou nan" and "Shao nan".
King Zhao of Zhou personally led an attack of chastisement against Chu,
Xin Yumi, who was both tall and very strong,
was on the king's right,
on the way back,while they were crossing the Han river,
the bridge collapsed.

and thus he became senior duke among feudal lords.
When Zhengjia of the Yin dynasty moved to West of the River,
he still missed his old home,
and as a result created tunes in the western style.
The senior duke continued to write these tunes when he resided in the western mountains.
When Duke Mu of Qin collected these airs,
it marked the beginning of the tunes of Qin.
The head of Song barbarians had two lovely daughters
and built the Terrace of Nine Tiers for them to live in.
They had to have music played whenever they ate and drank.
The supreme Sovereign ordered a swallow to spy on them.
Its cry sounded like "jik-rik."
Loving this, the two girls struggled to catch the swallow.
putting it in a jade canister,
they would take it out
to look at it for a short time.
The swallow, having laid two eggs,
flew off to the north,
never to return.
The two girls wrote a song,
with a refrain that went "Swallow, swallow, flew away."
This marked the beginning of the tunes in the northern style.
As a general rule, tunes
are products of the heart and mind of man.
When feelings are aroused in the heart, they are expressed in a melody.
melody that takes shape without is a transformation of what is within.
This explains how one knows the customs of a people from hearing their music.
By examining their customs, one knows their intentions.
By observing their intentions, one knows their Powers.
Wether a person is ascending or declining, worthy or unworthy,a gentleman or a petty man is given visible form in music
and cannot be hidden.
Hence, is said,"What is visible in music is profound indeed!"
Just as when the soil is poor, trees and grasses will not grow tall,
and when water is stirred up, fish and turtles will not grow large,
when the age is befouled, its rituals are in disaray and its music debauched.
The music of Zheng and Wey
and the tunes of Sangjian
are what chaotic states prefer,
what pleases rulers whose Power is in decline.
When drifting, frivolous, and reckless tunes develop,
wild ethers and depraved thoughts become contaminating influences. When they become contaminating influences, a hundred evils and a host of perversities are produced thereby.
Hence, the gentleman reverts to the Dao to cultivate his Power;
he corrects his Power in order to give expression to his music;
and he makes his music harmonious in order to become perfectly in accord with nature.
People will face toward the source of harmonious music.

RATTLING WEAPONS
CHAPTER 2
A. The ancient sage-kings held to the doctrine of the righteous use of weapons,and none thought of abolishing them.
Weapons originated in high antiquity, appearing at the same time as mankind.
B. As a general rule ,
weapons inspire fear,
and they inspire fear
because they are powerful.
That the people become fearful when confronted with power
is due to their essential nature as humans.
Their essential nature is what they receive from Heaven.
It is not something a man can contrive,
a soldier overturn,
or an artisan change.
C. Weopons originated long ago.
The Yellow Sovereign and the Yan used water and fire.
The Gonggong lacked restraint and created troubles.
The Five Sovereigns fought their respective battles.
Sometimes rising, sometimes falling,
the victor exercised authority.
Though men say
that Chiyou invented weapons,
he did not invent them;
rather, he merely improved the implements of war.
Even before the time of Chiyou, people fought with tree branches from which the bark had been peeled, and the victor became chieftain and governed them.
Chieftains proved unequal to the tasks of governing-
this is why the position of lord was established.
Lords also proved unequal to the tasks of governing-
this is why the position of Son of Heaven was established.
The positon of Son of Heaven developed out of that of lord;
that of lord in turn developed out of that of chief;
and that of chief developed from fighting.
Fighting and conflict orginated long ago,
so they can be neither forbidden nor halted.
Thus, the sage-kings of antiquity held to the doctrine of the righteous use of weapons,
and none thought of abolishning weapons.
When a family lacks a painful whip,
youngsters and children commit offenses in an instant.
When a state lacks punishment and penalties,
ministers and minor officials become aware that they can contravene the law, and common people commit offences against one another.
When the world lacks campagns of chastisement,
the feudal lords commit violence against one another.
Thus a painful whip cannot be abolished in the home,
punishment cannot be abolished in the state
and campaigns of chastisement cannot be abolished in the empire.
There are merely differences in how the skilled use them.
Thus,the sage-kings of antiquity held to the doctrine of the righteous use of weapons but none thought of abolishing the weapons.
Just as it would be perverse to forbid all food
because someone died from rancid food,
or
to forbid all boats
because someone died from riding in a boat,
so too
would it be perverse to abolish all the weapons
simply because someone lost his state using weapons.
The reason weapons cannot be abolished
is analogous to the reason why water and fire cannot be abolished.
if a person uses them skillfully, he enjoys good fortune;
if he uses them incapaply, he suffers calamity.
It is just the same as using herbal medicines:
if you procure a good herb,
you may kill someone.
Rightous weapons are the world's good herb, but they are even more important.
A. Furthermore, since weapons first originated long ago,
no one has ever, for instant, put them aside.
Noble and base, old and young, worthy and unworthy are all the same in this regard.
The only differense lies in the crudity or subtlety of their use of them.
Let us examine examples of weapons that the subtle use:
what lies in the heart but not expressed
is a weapon;
an angry glare is a weapon;
a change in facial expression is a weapon;
a proud word is a weapon;
pulling and pushing with the arms is a weapon;
linking and overturning with the legs is a weapon;
group fighting is a weapon;
the Three Armies' attacking is a weapon.
These eight are all weapons.
They are how the subtle contend with the crude.
Now those of the present age who anxiously advocate the abolition of weapons are perverse
in that they do not know that they live full lives only because they themselves use weapons.
Thus, though their persuasions are forceful,
their talk discriminating,
and their cultivation and learning broad,
they do not gain a receptive audience.
Hence, the sage-kings of antiquity held to the doctrine of the rightous use of weapons,
and none though of abolishing weapons.
B. The truly righteous employment of weapons
involves using them to punish tyrannical lords and relieve suffering peoples.
This pleases the people,
just as seeing his beloved parents delights a filial son
or seeing wonderful food pleases a starving man.
The people shout and run to the righteous army,
like a bolt from a powerful crossbow shot into a deep gorge
or like the water rushing from a great reservoir where the dike has failed.
If the allegiance of his people cannot be held by a middling ruler,
how much less could it be held by an evil one.

As a general principle, the inhabitants of the nine provinces of the world must, without exception, exert their full effort to supply what is required for the sacrifices to August Heaven, the Supreme Sovereign, the altars of soil and grain, and the mountains, forests, and famous rivers.

In three decades of days, . . . two days.

CHAPER 2
THE CODE OF A SCHOLARKNIGHT
A true scholar-knight
holds fast to his code without avoiding difficulties;
he approaches trouble unmindful of any benefit.
he "forgets life in doing what is right,"
ans "regards death as returning home."
Such men "are not friends
whom the lords of state can obtain"
nor "ministers whom the Son of Heaven can aquire."
The greatest accomplishment, that of settling the world,
and the next, that of settling a single state,
must proceed from such men.
Thus, if a ruler of men disires the greatness that will assure achievement and fame,
it is impossible for him not to devote himself to seeking such men.
Thus, it is said, "The worhty ruler takes pains in seeking men
but is at ease in managing tasks."
In Qi there was one Beiguo Sao
who knotted nets,
plaited ropes,
and wove straw shoes.
He did this to care for his mother, but the income he derived from it was insufficient.
He went in person to see Master Yan and said to him,
"I wish to beg from you what I need to care for my mother"
One of Master Yan's attendants said to master Yan,
"This man is a worthy of the state of Qi.
His code requires that he 'not be a minister to the Son of Heaven'
and that he 'not befriend the feudal lords.'
He does not seek profit at any cost
nor does he avoid harm a any cost.
Now he is begging what it needs to care for his mother.
He delights in your righteousness.
you must give him what he asks."
Master Yan sent a man to take a measure from the granary and the treasury and give it to him.
Baiguo Sao declined the money but took the grain.
After a short time,
Master Yan came to be doubted by the lord of Qi
and fled for his life.
passing the gate of Beibuo Sao, he took his leave of him.
Beiguo Sao came out from his bath. Seeing Master Yan, he asked,
"Where are you going?"
Master Yan replied,
"I am doubted by the lord of Qi
and am fleeing for my life."
Master Beiguo said,
"Hurry and go!"
Master Yan climbed into his carriage,
and expelling a great breath, he sighed,
"Is my demise not fitting indeed!
For I have not understood scholar-knights at all,"
Master Yan left.
Master Beiguo summoned a friend and reported the event to him, saying,
"I delighted in Master Yan's righteousness
and so once I begged from him what I needed to care for my mother.
I have heard it said,
'If someone cares for your parents,
you should shield him from difficulties with your own body.'
Now master Yan is doubted.
I will go risk my life to clear him.
Putting on his robe and cap,
he ordered his companion to follow with sword in hand and a hamper held high.
He respectfully entered his lord's courtyard
and pleaded to have Master Yan reinstated. He said,
"Master Yan
is the worthiest man in the world.
If he leaves, the state of Qi will surely be invaded.
I would rather die than have to see the invasion of my state.
I wish to offer my head
as a pledge to clear Master Yan."
He then told his companion,
"Put my head in the hamper
and offer it as a pledge.
Then withdraw and kill yourself."
His companion offered the head as a pledge.
He told those observing all this,
"Master Beiguo died for the state,
I am going to die for Master Beiguo."
He then withdrew and killed himself.
When the lord of Qi heard of it,
he became very upset.
Riding a quick horse, he himself went in pursuit of Master Yan
and caught up with him on the outskirts of the capital.
He requested that he return,
and Master Yan, because he had no choice, did return.
When he heard that Beiguo Sao had died to clear him,
he said,
"Is my demise not fitting indeed!
My understanding of scholar-knights was even less than I had thought."

STANDING ALONE
It is easy to hold onto others if you offer them honor and wealth.
But it is difficult to hold onto others if you offer them poverty and debasement.
When Duke Wen of Jin fled his state,
he wandered about the whole world,
impoverished and humiliated;
yet Jie Zitui did not abandon him,

because he now lacked what was needed to keep him.

SINCERITY AND PURITY

are part of their nature.
Nature is
what is received from Heaven

if they regard something as unimportant, they use it to develop the important.

records the principles that lead to order and anarchy, survival and destruction,

this trust is the guiding that leads to obedience.

The grouping together of ears, eyes, nose, and mouth
and the grouping together of the Five Foods and cold and heat
are called "grouping together of different things."
If different things are grouped together, the myriad things are all included.
Heaven arrays the myriad things,
and the sage observes them closely
to discover their proper category.
The explanation lies in what gives Heaven and Earth shape,
in what produces thunder and lightening,
in the refind essences by which Yin and Yang create things,
and in what comforts and pacifies humans and wild beasts
Whenever an emperor or universal king is about to arise,
Heaven is certain to manifest good omens to the people below.
At the time of the Yellow Sovereign,
Heaven first caused giant mole crickets and earthworms to appear.
The Yellow wovereign announced,
"the ethers of Earth are in ascendance".
he honored the color yellow
and modeled his activities on Earth.
When it came to the time of Yu,
Heaven first caused trees and grasses to appear that did not wither in autumn and winter.
Yu proclamed, "The ethers of wood are in ascendance."
Since the ethers of wood were ascendant,
he honored the color green
and modeled his affairs on Wood.
When it came to the time of Tang,
Heaven first caused metal blades to appear coming forth from Water.
Tang proclaimed "The ethers of Metal are in ascendance."
Since the ethers of Metal were ascendant,
he honored the color white
and modeled his affairs on Metal.
When it came to the time of King Wen,
Heaven first caused a fiery-red crow to appear and alight on the altars of Zhou, holding in its beak a document.
King Wen proclamed, "The ethers of Fire are in ascendance."
Since the ethers of fire were ascendant,
he honored the color vermillion
and modelled his affairs on Fire.
The successor to Fire is certain to be Water.
Heaven has again first given signs that the ethers of Water are in ascendance.
since the ethers of Water are are ascendant,
the ruler should honor the color black
and model his affairs on Water.
If the ethers of Water culminate and no one grasps that fact,
the period when it is effective will come to an end, and the cycle will shift to Earth.
"Heaven makes a season,
but will not assist farmers here below."
Things belonging to the same category naturally attract each other;
things that share the same ethers naturally join together;
and notes that are comparable naturally resonate to one another.
Strike the note gong on one instrument and the other strings tuned to the gong note will vibrate;
strike the note jue and other strings tuned to jue will vibrate.
Water flowing across leveled earth
will flow to the damp places;
light evenly stacked firewood,
and the fire will catch where it is driest.
Clouds above a mountain look like shrubs;
above water they resemblefish scales;
above an arid landscape they look like leaping fire;
above a flood they resemble rolling waves.
Without exception, everything manifests signs that show men it shares the same category with that which creates it.
Thus, use the dragon to bring rain,
and use a form to pursue a shadow. //
Whenever an army has camped,
brambles and briars are sure to grow.//
The natural occurence of fortune and misfortune
is considered by the masses to be a matter of destiny,
But how could they know its true source?
If you overturn the bird's nests and break their eggs,
phoenixes will not arrive.
If you cut open wild beasts and eat their fetuses,
unicorns will not come.
If you dry up marshes and strand
the fish in them, dragons will not appear.
All the ways in which things tha agree may coincide
cannot be recorded,
yet the son is not restrained by his parents,
nor the minister by his lord.
Where there is agreement, they come together;
where there is difference, they part.
Thus, although the minister honors his lord,
if he takes white to be black,
it will be impossible for the minister to heed him.
Although the son feels ties of kinship with his father,
if he takes black to be white,
his soncannot agree with him.
The Yellow Sovereign said:
So vas! So limitless!
I rely on the majesty of Heaven
and share with the Primordial the same ethers."
Hence it is said, "Sharing the same ethers is worthier than
sharing the same code of conduct,worthier than the same
accomplishments,worthier than the same circumstances; and
sharing the same circumstances is worthier than sharing the same reputation. "
Sovereigns share the same ethers,
true kings the same code of conduct,
and lords-protector the same accomplishments.
The dilligent, sharing the same circumstances, lack generosity;
and the doomed, sharing the same reputaion, are coarse.
the coarser one's awareness,
the coarser what one share;
the more refined one's awareness,
the more refined what one can share.
Hence, as a general principle, realization of one's goals cannot be accomplished except through refinement.
It was their refinement
that produced the perfection of the Five Sovereigns and the Three Kings.
When the categories are identical, everything is consistent.
Hence, "Yao did good, and everything that transpired was
good; Jie did evil and everything was evil. "
The admonitions of Shang say:
"Wether Heaven sends down a disaster or signals a good
omen, there is something responsible for it."
Hence, when a state is in disorder,
it does not merely remain in disorder but attracts bandits.
Were it to remain merely disordered,
it would not necessarily perish,
but because it attracts bandits, there is no way it can survive.
The general rule is that the military should be employed
for profit
and the moral right.
If a ruler attacks the disorderly, he acts morally,
and when they submit, he profits.
If he attacks the disorderly, he acts morally,
and in acting morally, he attains glory.
If even ordinary rulers secure profit
as well as glory from acting this way,
how much more will the worthy ruler!
Hence, ceding territory, offering treasured vessels,
apologizing humbly,and bowing in submission
are not enough to prevent attack.
Only order can accomplish that.
If a state is well-ordered, those who seek profit will not attack it
and those who look for fame will not make a campaign of chastisement against it.
As a generel rule, attacks and chastisements,
if not undertaken for the sake of profit, are assuredly undertaken for the sake of reputation.
If in fact a reputation cannot be made,
then even though the state is strong and large
why would it attack?
The explanation is found in Scribe Mo's coming and the Zhao's abandoning the surprise attack on Wei.
Viscount Jian of Zhao can indeed be called one who knew when to move and when to keep still.
In our age
those who judge frequently, have prejudices.
If a person have many prejudices, his judments are certain to be fallacious.
while the causes of prejudices are numerous,
the essential facts is
that they inevitably are grounded in what men like and dislike.
A person who looks east does not perceive the western wall;
one who views things to the south does not observe the northern direction.
Ideas are dependant on location.
There was a man who lost an ax
and suspected his neighbor's son.
He observed that his walk,
his expression,
and his words were those of a man who would steal an ax.
Every action and attitude of the youth betokened someone who would steel an ax.
Later, when the man was clearing a ditch, he found his ax.
When, on another day, he again saw his neighbor's son,
there was nothing in his actions or attidudes that resembled those of one who would steel an axe.
It was not his neighbor's son who had changed,
but the man himself who had changed.
This change had no other cause
than that he had been prejudiced.
According to an old law of Zhu,
armor always had to be bound together with pieces of silk.
Gong Xiji said to the lord of Zhu,
"It would be better to use fasteners.
The best way to always make armor stronger
is by filling all the gaps.
Now, in your armor the gaps are filled,
but a man can use only half his strength.
With fasteners, this would not be so.
The gaps would be filled, and the wearer could use his full strength."
The lord of Zhu thought that this was so
and said,
"How will you get the fasteners?"
Gong Xiji replied,
"If their superiors use them, the people will make them."
The lord of Zhu said,
"Good".
He sent down command
to the office in charge of making armor ordering that fasteners must now be used.
Gong Xiji knew that his advice would be put into effect
and so ordered his entire family to make fasteners.
Someone criticized him to the lord:
"The reason Gong Xiji wanted fasteners to be used
is because his family makes most of them."
The lord of Zhu was displeased
and so issued another command to the office in sharge of armor
ordering that fasteners not be used.
This was prejustice on the part of the lord of Zhu.
Armor made using fasteners was more convenient;
Even though Gong Xiji made the majority of the fasteners,
What harm was there in that?
If fasteners were not convenient,
then even if he did not make fasteners,
would he have benefited?
Thus, wether he made fasteners or not
was an insufficient ground for rejecting Gong Xiji's advice.
It was the reason for using fasteners
that should have been examined.
There was an ugly person in Lu.
While out his father happened to see Whang Duo.
When he returned home, he commented to his neighbor,
"Shang Duo does not equal my son."
Now his son was the extreme of ugliness
and Shang Duo was the extreme of handsomeness;
yet he considered extreme handsomeness inferior to extreme ugliness
because he was prejudiced by love.
Only one who knows the ugliness of beauty
and the beauty of ugliness,
therefore is capable of understanding true beauty and ugliness.
Zhuangzi said,

play for belt-hooks and you become combative;
play for gold and you come flustered.
Although your luck is the same in each of the games,
the reason you become flustered
must be the value you place on external things.
Valuing external things
makes one become clumsy within."
The man of Lu can be called someone who valued external things.
The explanation is found in the story of the man of Qi who desired to get gold
and in the Qin Mohists who were jealous of one another.
Both are examples of people being biased about something.
Lao Dan grasped the point.
If like a straight-growing tree you stand on your own
and never consort with the vulgar,
how can you improve on this?
The grounds for judging the quality of advice cannot but be carefully investigated.
If it is not carefully investigated, then the good and the not -good will not be properly characterized.
and there is no greater disorder
than when the good and the non-good are not properly characterized.
Because the three Dynasties properly characterized the good and the non-good
they became universal kings.
Today the worls is in ever greater decline,
and the Dao of the sage-kings has been cast aside and broken off.
Rulers of the present are for the most part concerned with increasing their pleasures and joys,
enlarging their bells and drums,
and creating the extravagant terraces, pavillions, gardens, and parks;
this is why they expropriate the resources of the others.
They think nothing of working their people to death
and so stir up their indignation.
The aged and weak freeze or starve to death.
The young and frail, even the robust and vigorous,
are exhausted,
which will lead to their death or enslavement.
These rulers attack guiltless states in their pursuit of territory
and execute innocent people in their search for profit.
and although they desire that their ancestral temples be secure and their altars to the soil and grain not be endangered,
are they not placed in even greater difficulty?
Suppose someone were to say,
"There is a certain party who has many goods,
the rear wall of his house has collapsed,
and his guard dog has died-
given these circumstances, we can rob him."
People would certainly reject this advice.
But if someone were to say:
"A certain state is starving,
its city walls are collapsing,
and its defensive weapons are few-
we should make sneakattack and annex it."
People would not reject this advice.
But if they do not, then they do not understand that both actions belong to the same category.
Characterizing the good and the not-good is rooted in benefiting
and in loving others.
He who makes loving and benefiting others his Dao is great indeed!
When a person has been wandering the seas
for a full month,
he is overjoyed when he sees anyone who looks familiar.
When he has been gone for a whole year,
he is overjoyed when he sees anything he once saw in the Central States.
The longer his absence,
the more profound his longing!
The people of our chaotic age
have also been long seperated from a sage-king.
they hope to see a sage-king,
seaselessly, day and night.
Thus, the worthy king and the eminent scholar-knight whose desire is to relieve the conditions of the black-haired commoners
cannot but strive to help them.
Achievement precedes a good reputation,
effective polecy precedes achievement,
and good advice precedes effective policy.
If a person does not recognize effective policies,how will he be capable of judging the quality of advice?
If he does not understand the true nature of things, how will he be capable of determining whether the advice suits the circumstances?
Between good advice and the chirping of fledgling birds,
is there a difference
or is there none?
The charioteer Zaofu begang his studies with Taidou.
Archer Pangmen began his studies with Ganying.
In driving with Taidou
and shooting with Ganying,
they did not vary from their methods and in this way took into account their own natures.
Because they did not vary,
the one was able to go great distances and chase the quick,
while the other could eliminate harm and prevent violence.
As a gneral principle, other men too must study their own hearts,
for only then will they be able to study by learning and questioning.
What you do not get by studying your own heart,
study by learning and questioning.
From antiquity to the present,
there has never been anyone who did not learn yet was able to judge persuaons.
The explanation is found in Bai gui's criticixing Hui Shi;
in Gongsun Long's persuading King Zhao of Yan to lay down his arms as well as in his responding to the encounter at Kongluo;
in Kong Chuan's debating with Gongsun Long;
and in Di Jian's showing the difficulties in the model of Hui Shi.
Because the arguments of these four scholar-knights
have very complicated reasoning,
they cannot but be independently analyzed.
In the past, during a single bath Yu once rolled up his hair three times
and during a single meal once arose three times,
thereby treating scholar-knights who possessed the Dao with the ritual courtesy,
and coming to understand those things in which he himself was inadequate.
If a person comes to understand those things in which he himself was inadequate,
he will not compete over external things.
Contented and in a state of repose,
he awaits knights who possess the Dao, causing them to obtain what they want.
Relying on what is so,
he recognizes them as they are, inducing them to advise him as they wish.
The rulers of doomed states are the opposite of this.
Thinking themselves worthy, they belittle others.
Since they belittles others, those who might offer persuasions keep their wisdom to themselves.
Those who think too highly of themselves do not reach the truth,
so even though they posessed the world, what benefit would it bring?
They confuse the dark with light,
disorder with stabiliry,
failure with success,
and danger with tranquillity.
Thus, Yin an Zhou perished
and Bigan died
because rulers were perverse and incaple of making plans.
Accordingly, the nature of rulers is such
that none of them errs with respect
to those whom they fail to doubt,
They do not err with respect to those whom they do not know,
but they do err with respect to those whom they already know.
Accordingly, even though you are not doubtful about someone
and even though you already know him,
it is necessary that you examine him in light of the model,
measure him using definite standards,
and test him using the accepted methods.
If you proceed in this fashion,
you will not err in those you pick and reject.
How did Yao obtain worthy men in the empire and test Shun?
How did Shun get worthy men in the empire an test Yu?
They mde their decisions simply by listening with their own ears.
They could decide by listening with their own ears
because they kept to the essential qualities of their inborn natures and natural endowment.
Today those who are confused
do not understand that they must keep to the essential qualities of their inborn natures and natural endowments.

How then could they personally understand the failures of their age [understand their own age!CH]
or their own inadequacies?
The highest state is to know something,
the next is to know that one does not know it.
If you are unable to do something,
study how to do it.
The admonitions of Zhou say:
"If one thinks intendently upon this,
it is not too late to cultivate Power."
It was by learning from the worthy and questioning the wise
that the Three Dynasties flourished.
A person who does not know but thinks that he knows,
is the progenitor of every kind of calamity.
A reputaion is not established by empty exertions,
accomplishments are not completed by themselves,
and a state is not preserved by nothing-
each requires a worthy person.
The Dao of the worthy person
is difficult to know, being indistinct,
and difficult to apprehend, being subtle.
Hence, anyone who sees a worthy and is not respectful of him feels no awe in his heart.
If he feels no awe in his heart, his understanding will not be deep.
Nothing presages greater calamity
than not having a deep understanding of the advice of worthy men.
When a ruler is worhty and the age is orderly, worthy persons occupy high positions.
When a ruler is unworthy and to age is disorderly, worthies occupy inferior positions.
Today, the house of Zhou has been annihilated,
and the line of the Son of Heaven cut off.
No disorder is worse than lacking a Son of Heaven,
for when there is no Son of Heaven,
there is no end to the strong conquering the weak,
the many tyrannizing the few,
and the armies destroying the people.
This is precisely what the present age faces.
Hence, if those in the present
seek scholar-knights who posess the Dao,
let them go throughout the lands within the four seas, to the mountains and the valleys,
and to places faraway and remote.
Perhaps they will be lucky and find them.
If they should find them,then what desire will be not be fulfilled and what undertaking not succeed?
The Grand Duke fished at Zi Spring,
living as he did in the age of Zhou Xin.
King Wen obtained the Grand Duke's services, he became king.
King Wen
was the ruler of a small state with a thousand chariots
while Zhou Xin
was the Son of Heaven.
The Son of Heaven missed the opportunity to use the Grand Duke while thousand-chariot ruler obtained him.
This is because they recognized his worth and the other did not.
Now, a ruler can use the masses of undistinguished commoners
without appreciating their individual worth,
and he can order them about without observing ritual courtesies.
But with the scholar-knights who possess the Dao,
a ruler certainly must observe ritual courtesy and appreciate their worth,
for only then will he obtain the full benefits of their knowledge and abilities.
The explanation is found in Sheng Shu's persuation of the Duke of Zhou-
who can properly be called "capable of heeding advice";
and in the audiences Duke Huan of Qi gave to lesser Minister Ji
and Marquis Wen of Wei gave to Tian Zifang-
both rulers can properly be called"capable of treating scholar-knights with ritual courtesy."
Judging from the records of high antiquity,
all the assistants of the Three Kings
had glorious reputations
and real comfort in their lives.
This was because they performed work of great merit.
An Ode says:
The sky is densely covered, //
With rising clouds, thick and ample. //
It rains on the public field, //
And then on our private lands. //
All assistants of the Three Kings
were able to benefit the public good as well as their own private interests.
Assistants to ordinary kings
share the same desire for reputation and comfort as the assistants of the Three Kings.
But without exception they acquire shameful reputations
and encounter personal danger.
This occurs because they have no concern for the public good.
All are concerned that they [THEMSELVES!] are not honored in the state,
but they do not worry that their ruler is not honored in the world.
They are concerned that their family is not wealthy,
but they do not worry that their state is not large.
In this way, the more a person seeks glory, the greater his disgrace becomes,
and the more he desires security, the greater his personal danger.
The foundation of a security and danger, glory and disgrace, rests with the ruler.
The foundations of the ruler rests in the ancestral temple.
The foundation of the ancestal temple rests in the people.
And order or disorder among the people rests in those who manage official affairs.
The Changes says:
"Returen to following the Dao.
What blame could there be in this?
Good fortune."
This says that there is no deviation from the proper way of carrying out one's duties, one's actions will end joyfully.
Now, however, when men occupy office, they become wild and disorderly;

and when they lead the multitudes they are cowardly.
It is not indeed difficult
to realize expectations of riches from the ruler in this way.
Now consider the case of a person
who considers it shameful to devote himself to keeping accurate accounts.
Such a man will regard gorverment goods and moneys as his own.
Were he to be wealthy,
he could only have acquired his wealthby being a thief.
Accordingly, glory and wealth do not come on their own;
they are tied to effort and exertion.
Now, to claim that one can expect riches through very little effort or exertion
is a lie,
and to claim that one can seek glory and riches without having made any effort
is a falsehood.
The way of lies and falsehoods
is not followed by the gentleman.
People who engage in deliberations often argue that
"if my superior would but employ me, I could garantee that the state would have no troubles."
Even of they were employed, they could not guarantee that.
It would be best for them to make themselves worthy.
If they have troubles of their own,
how will the state not suffer troubles
if they work for it?
The self
is what one can regulate.
To ignore what you can regulate
and be energetic in what you cannot regulate
is perverse.
That such a person should never govern a state or manage a burau is fitting.
As for "serving parents within
and making friends without,"
this is certainly something that is possible to accomplish.
If someone is not filial when serving parents
and not dependable in relations with friends,
how could one approve of him,
having not accomplished even this?
Thus, one should judge men, not on the basis of what they have never done,
but on the basis of what they have already done.
On the basis of what they have done already, one can know what will they never be capable of.
In antiquity, those who served lords
invariably were entrusted with responsibility only after they had demonstrated their abilities;
and they invariably accepted emoluments only after they had kept to their essential natures.
Even if rulers made excessive generoous offers,
their ministers would not accept them for doing nothing.
One of the Greater odes says,
The Supreme Sovereign looks over you, //
Have no theachery in your hearts. //
With these words the Ode describes the conduct of a loyal minister.
The explanations are to be found in the case of the lord of Zheng's asking the opinion of Bei Zhan
and in Bo Yi's advising Lord Si of Wey that he should not stress taxation.
These two scholar-knights both approached an understanding of the fundamentals.
Formerly, Shun desired to be a standard for antiquity and the present, but he was not successful

Yu wanted to be a Sovereign but he was not successful
although he was able to correct odd customs.
Tang desired to carry on the example of Yu, but he did not succed

although he was able to spread the Dao of true kingship.

although they were able to serve as chiefs of the feudal lords.
Confucius and Mo Di wanted to practece the Great Way in their own ages, but were not successful

Hence, even when great ideals are not realized,
there is still something that can be realized.
A document of Xia says.
"The power of the Son of Heaven is exercised across a broad cycle,
Sometimes sage-like, sometimes spirit-like,
Sometimes martial, sometimes civil."
therefore, devote your efforts
to great goals.
Because the earth is large, it contains the mountains Changxiang, Buting, Qimu, Qundi, Tiandi, and Buzhou.

it is possible to observe oddities.

There are no ponds in a hollow,
no large fish in a well,
and no tall trees in a grove.
As a general principle, in laying plans for things that will succeed,

Master Ji said:

Mother birds feed their fledglings,
which coo happily to one another
and feel themselves secure.

the fire willspread up along the rafters;
yet why is it
the swallows do not change their manner?

Officials who are able to avoid being such birdbrains are few.
They
advance their titles, emoluments, fortunes, and homor.
Father and sons, older and younger brothers form cliques in a single state,
cooing happily to one another,
and thereby endanger their altars to the soil and grain.
They are unaware of
how close they are to crack in the stove,
and so finally their wisdom is no greater than that of swallows
Therefore it is said:
'When the world is in a state of total anarchy,
no country is secure;
when the whole country is in utter chaos,
no family is secure.
when the whole family is in total disorder,

This express my meaning.
The settling of the small, therefore, invariably depends on the large,
and the securing of the large inevitably depends on the small.

are connected to each other,

His point is that the settling of the base and the small depends on the honored and the large.
The explanations are found in the cases of Bo Yi's persuading Lord Si of Wey to use kingly methods,
in Du He's persuading Lord Zhaowen of Zhou to pacify the world,

As a general principle, in order to govern the world and put a nation in good order,
it is necessary to devote one's efforts first to the root fundamentals and only then to the nonessential branches.
By "root fundamentals" we mean
not plowing and hoeing, planting and cultivating,
but seeking the right men.
Seeking the right men.
is not the matter of enrichning those who are poor
or giving much to those who have little,
but is working on the root fundamentals.
In working on the root of the fundamentals, nothing is more prized than beeing filial.
If the ruler is filial,
his name will be illustrious,
those below will obey him,
and the world will sing his praises.
If a minister is filial,
he will serve his lord loyalty,
manage his official duties honestly,
and confront difficulties even though they might lead to his death.
If knight-scholars and commoners are filial,
they will tend to agriculture diligently,
be stalwart in defending and doing battle,
and never run from defeat.
Filial piety is the root fundamental
to which the Three August Ones and the Five Sovereigns devoted themselves;
it is the guiding thread that runs through the myriad undertakings.
The person who holds fast to one method in order to bring a hundred good things, who expels one hundred bad things, and is followed by the world
can only be a filial man.
Thus, in judging others, you must consider first how they treat their parents and then how they treat those moere distantly related,
first how they regard as important and then how they treat what they regard as less important.
Now, when a person
acts with filial respect and strict care toward his parents and toward what is important
and when he is not lax or lazy toward the less important and more distant,
then he is reliably conscientious about the Dao of filial piety.
This is how the Former Kings brought order to the world.
"the person who loves his parents
dares not hate others,
who respects his parents
dares not be irrelevant toward others,
and who is utterly loving and respectful in serving his parents
will brightly spread his light upon the Hundred Clans
and reach to all within the four seas."
Such is the filial piety of the Son of Heaven.
Master Zeng said,
"Your body
is the material form bequeathed you by father and mother.
In using this material form bequeathed you by father and mother,
dare you be disrespectful of it?"
A person who is undignified at home and rest,
disloyal in serving his lord,
careless in managing his official duties,
undependable with friends,
or lacks courage in battle
is not filial.
A son who fails to carry out these five kinds of filial conduct
will bring calamity to his parents.
Dare anyone be direcpectful in these matters?"
A Document of Shang says:
"Of the punishments for the three hundred crimes,
none is more severe than that exacted for being unfilial."

honoring the virtuous;
honoring th noble;
honoring the aged;
respecting those of senior rank;
and being compassionate with the young.

because they approached being sages.

what cause is there for my lord to be concerned about this?"

when will they cooperate?

he takes Heaven as his model //

did he not personally bow down to scholar-knights?

discuss ideas,
evaluate proper conduct,

when Di Huang was displeased,

In the past, when Zhao Xuanmeng was on his way up to Jiang,
he saw a starving man who was lying beneath a withered mulberry,
unable to rise.
Xuanmeng stopped his carriage
and handed some food down for the man.
He selected bits of dried meat and little by little fed him these.
Only after choking on it several times was the man able to see.
Xuanmeng asked him,
"How is it that you came to be starving like this?"
"Your servant was an official in Jiang,"
the man replied.
"When returning home, my supplies ran out.
I was ashamed to resort to begging and hated the idea of stealing for myself.
So I ended up as you find me."
Xuanmeng shared strip of dried meat with him.
The man bowed and accepted it but did not dare eat it.
When asked why,
the man replied,
"Your servant has an aged mother.
I am going to keep it to give to her."
Xuanmeng said,
" Eat it
and I will give you more for her."
He then presented the man with another two bunches of dried meat as well as a hundred pieces of cash
and then took leave of him.
Two years later,
Duke Ling of Jin wanted to have Xuanmeng killed.
He had a knight hide in a chamber to await him.
He then set out liquor for Xuanmeng.
Xuanmeng knew about the plan
and so left in the middle of drinking.

Xuanmeng asked,
"But what is your name?"
Turning as he ran back, the man said,
"What difference would my name make?
Your servant is the man who was starving beneath the withered mulberry."
Going back to the court, the man died fighting.
As a consequence, Xuanmeng was able to survive.
This is what a Document calls "virtue that seems to lack any smallness."
Because Xuanmeng was virtuous to a single knight, he was able to survive.
How much more would have been the return had he been virtous to ten thousand men?

and hot in summer,

He then passed through Wulu, and proceeded to Qi,
where Duke Huan of Qi had died.
He left Qi for Cao.
When Duke Gong of Cao saw that Chong'er had linked ribs,
he had him strip naked and catch fish in his pool.
Chong'er left cao, and passed through Song,
where Duke Xiang treated him with special courtesy.
He then went to Zheng,
where Duke Wen was disrespectful.
Bei Zhan remonstrated with the duke, saying,
"I have heard it said that a worthy ruler does not persecute those who are experiencing hardship.
Now, the followers of the prince of Jin
are all worthy,
and if your lordship will not treat him as protocol requires,
it would be best to kill him now."
The lord of Zheng did not heed the warning.
Chong'er left Zheng and traveled tooChu,
where King Cheng was rude to him.
He left Chu and went to Qin,
and Duke Mu restored him to power in Jin.
When affairs in Jin were settled,
Duke Wen raised an army to attack Zheng,
and he sought out Bei Zhan.
Bei Zhan said to the lord of Zheng,
"It would be best to hand me over to him."
"But I, the Unworthy One, am at fault,"
protested the lord of Zheng.
"By killing your subject, you can spare your state.
This is what I hope for."
Bei Zhan then surrendered to the Jin army.
As Duke Wen was about to have him boiled alive,
Bei Zhan grabbed hold of the pot and shouted,
"All you knights of the Three Armies listen to me.
From now on
do not bother to be loyal to your lord,
for whoever is loyal will be boiled alive."
Duke Wen let him go,
disbanded his army,
and returned home from Zheng.
Furthermore, because of Bei Zhan's loyalty to his lord, his lord avoided problems with Jin,
and because he practised morality in Zheng, he was viewed with pleasure by Duke Wen.
Thus, the benefits brought about by morality are ectensive.
The Mohist leader Meng Sheng
was on good terms with the Lord of Yangcheng,
so the Lord of Yangcheng made him protector of his fief in Chu.
Breaking a jade half-circle in two as a token,
each took the oath,
"Only when the halves are joined, will I obey an order."
When King Dao of Chu died,
his ministers and vassals attacked Wu Qi.
There was fighting at the burial ground
in which Lord Yangcheng participared.
Chu condemned him for that
and so the Lord of Yangcheng fled
When Chu tried to appropriate his state,
Meng Sheng said,

I have not received the token,
yet I do not have the power to resist,
so I must
be prepared to die."

you would also be cutting off the transmission of Mohism to later generations.

"That is not so,"
said Meng Sheng.
With the Lord of Yangcheng,
I was not only a teacher but a friend,
not only a friend but a subject.
If I do not die,
from this day forward,
Mohists will not be sought as serious teachers,
worthy friends,
and good subjects.
By dying I can progagate the code of conduct of the Mohist school and carry on its tasks.

Tian Xiang is worthy.
Why need we be concerned that Mohism shall be cut off?"
